description: From Middle English prone, proone, proon, from Latin prōnus (“turned forward, bent or inclined”), from prō (“forward”).

adjectives.description: prone (comparative proner or more prone, superlative pronest or most prone)

entries.meaning: Of the hand, forearm or foot: turned facing away from the body; with the thumb inward or big toe downward.
examples: the hand is in the prone position typically when using a keyboard; and the forearm is then also in the prone position; when the foot is resting on the inner side of the sole, it is in the prone position.

entries.meaning: Having a downward inclination or slope.

verbs.description: prone (third-person singular simple present prones, present participle proning, simple past and past participle proned)

entries.meaning: (medicine) To place in a prone position, to place face down.
